Attacker Objectives: Gain control of the braking system
Obtain sensitive data related to braking system

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker remotely accesses the vehicle's braking system via a vulnerable telematics interface, exploiting weak authentication mechanisms to gain control.
The attacker uses malware in a connected device, such as a smartphone app, to manipulate commands sent to the braking system.
An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and connects a malicious device to the OBD-II port to modify braking system settings.
A disgruntled employee with insider knowledge of the braking system's software uses their access to implement malicious changes that compromise the system.
An attacker captures unencrypted network traffic between the vehicle and service infrastructure to discover sensitive commands and credentials for the braking system.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized control of the braking system
Cause braking failure or unresponsive behavior

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the vehicle's firmware update mechanism accessed through the Internet to inject malware into the braking system.

Attack Vectors.vector_name: Physical Access to Onboard Diagnostics Port

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker connects a malicious device to the car's OBD-II port, uploading malware that targets the braking system's software.
An attacker distributes a compromised mobile app that, once installed, communicates with the vehicle and deploys malware targeting the braking control system.
An attacker infiltrates the supply chain of the vehicle manufacturers, introducing malware into components that later compromise the braking system once installed in vehicles.

Attacker Objectives: Manipulate vehicle functionality for malicious purposes

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker infiltrates a component supplier's infrastructure to insert malicious code into braking system components before they are shipped to automotive manufacturers.
Using social engineering, an attacker persuades a supplier to deliver compromised firmware updates, which then corrupt the braking system's software.
An attacker intercepts the shipment of braking system components and replaces them with tampered parts that have hidden vulnerabilities.
An attacker modifies the logistics tracking system to ensure that only altered components reach the manufacturing facility, bypassing quality checks.
An attacker introduces malware into a widely used third-party software library that interfaces with the braking system, compromising vehicle management systems that utilize this library.
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the supply chain software used for managing orders and inventory, gaining access to sensitive product data regarding braking systems.

Attacker Objectives: Damage the reputation of the automotive manufacturer

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker uses a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack to overwhelm the communication network of the braking system, causing delays or failures in brake signal processing.
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the vehicle's software update mechanism to upload a malicious firmware that disables the braking system.
An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and disables the brake system by severing crucial wiring, causing a complete loss of braking capability.

Attack Vectors.vector_name: Unauthorized access to brake system components

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker gains access to the undercarriage of a vehicle and physically alters brake lines to reduce brake effectiveness.
An attacker removes the wheel from a car and tamper with the brake caliper to prevent proper braking, leading to potential accidents.
An attacker replaces original brake pads with counterfeit, substandard parts which wear out quickly, causing brake failure.
An attacker posing as a service technician gains temporary access to modify braking system calibration settings during routine maintenance.

Attacker Objectives: Gain control of infotainment system features
Spy on users through installed applications

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker connects to the vehicle's Wi-Fi network and exploits weaknesses in the security protocol to access the infotainment system.
An attacker pairs a malicious device with the infotainment system via Bluetooth to gain unauthorized access.
An attacker tricks the user into installing a malicious application on the infotainment system that grants the attacker remote access.
An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and uses an USB device to exploit vulnerabilities in the infotainment system.

Attacker Objectives: Gather personal or financial data for identity theft

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker installs malware on the infotainment system through a compromised USB drive, allowing unauthorized access to personal data.
An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the infotainment system's Wi-Fi module to remotely access user data transmitted over the network.
An attacker sends a phishing message to the infotainment system via Bluetooth, tricking the user into providing sensitive information.

Attacker Objectives: Intercept communications within the infotainment system
Manipulate user settings for malicious purposes

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker creates a legitimate-looking mobile app that, once installed, harvests data from the vehicle's infotainment system by exploiting vulnerabilities in the app's permissions.
An attacker connects to the car's infotainment system via Bluetooth, using a previously compromised smartphone to siphon data such as call logs, messages, and location history.
A rogue Wi-Fi hotspot mimics a legitimate network, luring the car's infotainment system to connect and allowing the attacker to intercept data and inject malicious commands.
The attacker manages to push a counterfeit software update to the infotainment system, which embeds spyware into the system, allowing continuous data collection and remote monitoring.
An attacker places a malware-infected USB drive in a public space, enticing the vehicle owner to plug it into the infotainment system for updates, thereby installing the malware.
An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot near a parked vehicle. When the car connects to this network, the attacker exploits the connection to inject malware into the infotainment system.
An attacker develops a mobile app that appears legitimate but contains hidden malware. When the user installs the app to control infotainment features, the malware is installed onto the system.
An attacker compromises the software update mechanism of the vehicle manufacturer, sending out updates that contain malware disguised as legitimate updates.

Attacker Objectives: Inject malicious content into the infotainment system

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: The attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot near the vehicle, enticing users to connect. Once connected, the attacker can intercept all data transmitted between the infotainment system and external servers.
The attacker uses a Bluetooth device to emulate a trusted device. When the infotainment system connects, the attacker can intercept and modify the data sent to and from the connected devices.
The attacker gains access to the cellular network infrastructure, allowing them to intercept and manipulate data transmitted over the network to the infotainment system.

Attacker Objectives: gain unauthorized access to user behaviors

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker intercepts communication between the vehicle's GPS and the cloud service to capture real-time location data.
An attacker uses a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot to trick the vehicle's infotainment system into connecting, enabling data interception of location requests.
An attacker uses network analysis tools to capture unencrypted packets that contain location data transmitted between the vehicle and external services.
An attacker operates in close proximity to a vehicle, using a network sniffer to intercept location data broadcasted by connected devices.
An attacker exploits outdated software in the vehicle's communication system, allowing them to eavesdrop on location data being transmitted.
An attacker identifies and exploits weaknesses in the GPS or V2X communication protocols to gain unauthorized access to sensitive location data.

Attacker Objectives: Gain access to sensitive location data
Sell location data on the dark web
Use location data to track individuals
Manipulate location data for fraudulent purposes

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: The attacker sends a fraudulent email disguised as a legitimate request for location data, tricking the recipient into clicking a malicious link that compromises their credentials.
The attacker distributes malware that infiltrates devices storing location data, allowing unauthorized access and transfer of sensitive information.
The attacker intercepts communications on an unsecured network, capturing location data as it is transmitted between devices.
A disgruntled employee with access to location data decides to share sensitive information with external parties for monetary gain.
An attacker deploys malware to manipulate the location data stored in the vehicle's navigation system, leading to incorrect routing information.
During a data transmission between the vehicle and the cloud, an attacker intercepts and alters the location data in real-time.
An attacker uses a GPS signal generator to send false location data to the vehicle, causing it to misinterpret its actual position.
An attacker poses as a trusted service technician to gain physical access to the vehicle and manually alter the location data settings.

An attacker uses a GPS jamming device to disrupt the GPS signals received by the vehicle, causing the navigation system to fail. In the absence of accurate location data, the attacker then uses a spoofed GPS signal to redirect the vehicle to a predetermined location.

The attacker transmits counterfeit GPS signals that appear legitimate to the vehicle's navigation system, tricking it into believing it is at an alternate location. This could enable the attacker to reroute the vehicle or deceive location services regarding its true whereabouts.

An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in a vehicle's companion mobile application that utilizes location data. By leveraging these exploits, they manipulate the app to display false location information, affecting the vehicle's operational decisions based on this flawed data.

Attacker Objectives: gain unauthorized access to driving habits data
extract sensitive information for resale or exploitation

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker sends a fraudulent email to employees of the automotive company, enticing them to click on a link that leads to a fake login page to harvest credentials.
An attacker compromises a user's device with malware that captures keystrokes and sends the collected credentials back to the attacker, allowing access to the driving habits data.
An attacker discovers and exploits a vulnerability in an API used to access driving habits data. By sending crafted requests, the attacker retrieves sensitive data without authorization.
An attacker steals a laptop or mobile device belonging to an employee that contains unencrypted driving habits data, allowing access to sensitive information.
An attacker sends a convincing email to the user, tricking them into providing their login credentials to access their driving habits data.
An attacker identifies and exploits a vulnerability in the application that stores driving habits data, gaining unauthorized access to the database.
An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute force attack on user login credentials to gain access to the driving habits data.
An attacker collects leaked credentials from other breaches and employs them to gain access to user accounts within the driving habits application.
An employee with access to the driving habits data misuses their privileges to sell sensitive information to third parties.
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the driving habits database through SQL injection, allowing them to modify records.
An attacker intercepts data transmitted between the vehicle and the cloud service, altering driving data before it is stored.
Malware is installed on the vehicle's infotainment system, allowing an attacker to access and change driving habits data.
An attacker uses social engineering techniques to trick an employee into providing credentials to access driving habits data.

Attacker Objectives: Create detailed profiles for social engineering attacks

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: Malicious actors intercept driving habits data during transmission over unsecured networks, capturing information like routes, speed habits, and locations visited.
Attackers create a fake app disguised as a driving coach which, once installed, collects data on driving habits and sends it back to the attackers for profiling.
An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in connected car systems, gaining access to the onboard systems to extract driving data directly.
Attackers send phishing emails or messages to drivers purporting to be from a trusted source, enticing them to click a link that installs malware for data collection.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to sensitive information

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker deploys malware through a compromised update that corrupts the vehicle's storage, affecting navigation data.
An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and uses a device to alter the data on the in-vehicle storage directly.
An attacker hijacks the vehicle's Wi-Fi connection to introduce corrupt files or alter existing data within the in-vehicle storage.

Attacker Objectives: Manipulate stored data for fraudulent purposes
Gain access to user accounts linked with the vehicle
Create unauthorized access points for further attacks

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and uses a device to connect to the in-vehicle storage, extracting data directly.
An attacker installs malware through an unsecured vehicle entertainment system, allowing remote access to the in-vehicle storage.
An attacker exploits weaknesses in Bluetooth or Wi-Fi connectivity to intercept communications with the in-vehicle storage, obtaining sensitive data.
An attacker sets up a rogue access point that the vehicle connects to, allowing them to intercept and access stored data.
An attacker impersonates a vehicle service technician to trick the owner into providing access credentials for the in-vehicle system, allowing unauthorized data access.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems
Steal sensitive data from the vehicle
Establish a persistent presence within the vehicle's network

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker plants a USB drive infected with malware, which is then used by an unsuspecting user to connect to the vehicle's diagnostic port, executing the malware.
An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the vehicle's OTA update mechanism to inject malicious code during the software update process.
An attacker uses a compromised mobile device to connect to the vehicle's Bluetooth system, where they deploy malware that takes control of the vehicle's infotainment system.
An attacker creates a malicious mobile application that appears legitimate, tricking users into installing it which in turn infiltrates the vehicle's system through the mobile app connection.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to stored data

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and connects a device to the storage unit, allowing them to extract or tamper with data.
The attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the vehicle's wireless communication protocols to gain remote access to the storage system and extract sensitive data.
Through a compromised software update, the attacker injects malware into the vehicle's storage, allowing them to gain persistent access to the vehicle's systems.
An employee with access to the vehicle's internal systems exploits their privilege to access and manipulate the storage for malicious purposes.
An attacker gains physical access to the vehicle and connects a device to the OBD-II port to extract data and manipulate the vehicle's ECU.

An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the wireless interfaces (such as Bluetooth or Wi-Fi) to communicate with the vehicle's OBD-II system, allowing unauthorized access to vehicle diagnostics and control.
An attacker identifies and exploits software vulnerabilities in diagnostic tools that connect through the OBD-II port, gaining unauthorized access to the vehicle's systems.
An attacker uses social engineering techniques to convince a car service employee to provide access to the OBD-II port or install malicious diagnostic equipment.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems
Enable remote control of the vehicle

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker uses physical access to connect to the OBD-II port with a malicious device to exploit vehicle vulnerabilities.
An attacker uses a USB device containing malware plugged into the OBD-II port to gain control over the vehicle's electronic systems.
An attacker connects a smartphone to the OBD-II port that has been previously compromised, allowing the attacker to remotely exploit vulnerabilities in vehicle networks.
An attacker forges a software update to be introduced through the OBD-II port, which contains backdoors to the vehicle's systems.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker connects a malicious device to the OBD-II port, which installs malware onto the vehicle's electronic control unit (ECU) for control over vehicle functions.
Using a custom OBD-II adapter that contains preinstalled malware, an attacker collects sensitive data such as VIN, speed, and diagnostic information, then exfiltrates it via LTE or Wi-Fi.
An attacker compromises the software update mechanism of the vehicle's ECU via the OBD-II port, injecting malware during a legitimate update process.

An attacker develops a rogue mobile application that claims to provide vehicle diagnostics and encourages users to connect their phone to the OBD-II port, which in turn uploads malware to the vehicle.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker physically connects a rogue device to the OBD-II port to capture real-time diagnostic information.
An attacker uses a laptop with malicious software to connect to the OBD-II port and retrieve vehicle data.
An attacker sets up a rogue Bluetooth device that initiates a connection to the vehicle's onboard system while in proximity.
An attacker captures data transmitted between the vehicle and diagnostic tools over Wi-Fi using a man-in-the-middle attack.
An attacker deploys malware on a diagnostic tool used by technicians that records and sends vehicle data to an external server.
An attacker sends a malicious update to the vehicle's software that creates a backdoor to intercept diagnostic data.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems
Steal sensitive data from the vehicle
Replicate the malware across multiple vehicles

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker uses a USB drive preloaded with malware and connects it to an automotive diagnostic port during a routine service, allowing the malware to be injected into the vehicle's system.
An unsuspecting mechanic, believing the USB is a legitimate update tool, inserts the USB into the vehicle during maintenance, triggering malware execution.
An attacker compromises a USB keyboard or mouse used in automotive systems, designing it to execute malicious commands when connected.
An attacker poses as a technology service provider, convincing a technician to use a corrupted USB stick under the pretext of a software update for vehicle systems.
An attacker connects a compromised USB flash drive to the vehicle's data port, which automatically executes malware designed to extract data.
An attacker creates a fake USB device that appears legitimate but is rigged to siphon sensitive data from the vehicle's system upon connection.
An attacker uses social engineering tactics to convince an employee to insert a USB drive containing malware into the vehicle's system.
An attacker inserts a malicious USB drive into the vehicle's USB port to exploit vulnerabilities in the vehicle's infotainment system.
The attacker creates a replica of a legitimate USB device used for diagnostics, which is then used to access and manipulate critical vehicle systems.
An attacker uses a USB drive to upload compromised firmware to the vehicle's control systems, allowing them to take control of vehicle functions.

Attacker Objectives: Gain unauthorized access to vehicle systems
Extract sensitive data from the vehicle

Attack Scenarios.scenario_description: An attacker plugs a compromised USB device into the vehicle's port, which installs malware that allows remote access to the vehicle's systems.
An attacker uses a vulnerability in the vehicle's USB control software, utilizing a specially crafted USB device to execute arbitrary code on the vehicle's embedded systems.
An attacker connects a keylogger USB device that records events and credentials entered through the vehicle's control interface, allowing the attacker to exploit the vehicle later.
